blocks.title: Thank you for participating!
blocks.ask: Your response has been recorded. To receive your payment, please enter the following code in the submission box on Turk.
Confirmation Code: 8x2b47
We will send your payment within one week.
Please close your browser to exit.

blocks.title: Test
blocks.ask: Thank you for taking this survey. You really rock.
blocks.description: Because this set has no buttons, the participant will not be able to navigate to a different part of the survey.

blocks.title: Example Map
blocks.ask:
The interactive map to the left demonstrates the basic design and functionality of the maps you will see in the survey, although using silly map symbols.

Map Interactions

The interactive map includes three interactive features:

1. Zoom into and out of the map using your mouse wheel, double-clicking on the map, or using the zoom buttons to change the level of detail (zooming is constrained to only two map scales).

2. Pan by grabbing and dragging the map to recenter on an area of interest (panning is constrained to the study area).

3. Retrieve details about the number of tweets at a specific location by clicking on the map.

Try each of these interactions now.

blocks.title: Example Map
blocks.ask:
Map Legend

The map legend explains the meaning of the map symbols, which vary from map to map. The maps show the distribution of tweets in Western Kansas, with each map presenting a different topic (e.g., entertainment, fashion, food, sports). Tweet maps are depicted at two scales when zooming: tweets are aggregated by U.S. county by default when zoomed out and by “township” (6 mile by 6 mile subunits) when zoomed in.

Volume of tweets about PIZZA.


All legends have five classes.

blocks.title: Example Map
blocks.ask:
Example Questions

The map tasks are timed, so please do not divert your attention when completing the map tasks. The confidence and difficulty questions are not timed, so take your time in answering these follow-up questions. Example questions include:
  • Compare
  • Rank
  • Confidence
  • Difficulty
Try answering these questions now by interacting with the map. We are not collecting your responses to these example questions, so please take your time to get comfortable with the survey format.
1. Compare: Which CITY had more tweets about PIZZA?

2. Rank: Rank these CITIES according to their volume of tweets about PIZZA.
Drag each block to reorder.
(1 = the highest rank and 3 = lowest rank.)

3. Confidence: On a scale of 1-7, how CONFIDENT are you in your answer.
(1 = Not Confident, 7 = Very Confident)

4. Difficulty: On a scale of 1-7, how EASY was it to arrive at this answer using the map.

(1 = Very Difficult, 7 = Very Easy)

blocks.title: Participant Consent Form
blocks.ask:
Title of this Study: Elements of Interactive Cartography

Principle Investigator:
Robert E. Roth, PhD
375 Science Hall
N. Park Street
Madison, WI 53706
Phone: 608-262-1453; Email: reroth@wisc.edu

Description of Research:
You are invited to participate in a study to improve the design of interactive maps on the web. Specifically, the study investigates how we should design online maps that depict statistical information.

What will my participation involve?
If you decide to participate in this research, you will complete a survey that requires you to answer a series of tasks using different map designs. The survey will take approximately 25 minutes to complete.

Are there any risks to me?
Risk to participation is minimal. Thus, there are no foreseeable physical or mental risks to participation beyond those encountered in the normal course of everyday life.

Are there any benefits to me?
Your responses to the survey will be used to develop a better understanding of the design of interactive and online maps.

Will I be compensated for my time?
You will be compensated $3.50 for your participation upon completing the survey.

How will my confidentiality be protected?
No personally identifiable or sensitive information will be collected or maintained. Only group characteristics will be reported in publications of research findings.

Whom should I contact if I have questions?
You may ask any questions about the research at any time. If you have questions about the research after you leave today you should contact Robert E. Roth, PhD (PI) at 608-262-1453. If you are not satisfied with response of research team, have more questions, or want to talk with someone about your rights as a research participant, you should contact the Education Research and Social & Behavioral Science IRB Office at 608-263-2320. Your participation is completely voluntary and you can withdraw from the study at any time without compensation.

If you agree to take part in this research study as outlined above, please click 'Next' below. Selecting this button means that you understand your rights as a participant and AGREE to participate in this research study.

Close your browser if you choose NOT to participate.

blocks.title: Instructions and Eligibility
blocks.ask:
Thank you for agreeing to participate!

Maps and geographic information are increasingly common in daily life! You may be familiar with mapping services like Apple Maps, Google Maps, and MapQuest. You also may make use of web maps in social media like Facebook, Foursquare, Instagram, and Twitter. Further, you might have explored more complex interactive maps in popular news outlets like the New York Times and the Washington Post. The purpose of this study is to learn how we should design these maps.

INSTRUCTIONS
In the following survey, you will be shown different web map designs that depict the volume of tweets in Western Kansas. Twitter is a social media platform allowing users to submit short messages (i.e., tweets) that include a mappable location. The volume of tweets often is used as a proxy for public interest and engagement around different topics (e.g., entertainment, fashion, food, sports). The tweet topic will change from map to map, such that each tweet map pattern you will see is unique.

The survey has three parts:
  • PART 1: You will be presented with an example map. You will be asked to interact with this map to explore it's functionality. You will not be tested on this map. It is for training purposes only.
  • PART 2: You will be presented with 16 different maps and answer questions about map patterns as you interact with the maps. The map tasks are timed, so please do not divert your attention when completing the map tasks.
  • PART 3: The survey closes with questions about your preferences, interests, and experiences, as well as an exit background survey.
You will be compensated after completing these sections and the exit survey!

ELIGIBILITY
Before beginning, please once again review your eligibility for participating in the study: These restrictions greatly impact your responses.
  • You must be 18 years of age or older.
  • You must be fluent in English.
  • You must currently be living in the United States, but not in Kansas due to familiarity with the tested Geography
  • You do not have color vision impairment (i.e., are colorblind).
  • You must complete the survey on a non-mobile device, such as a laptop or desktop computer. Completing the experiment on a smartphone or small screen tablet will greatly impact your performance and skew results.


Click “Next” to confirm that you have read the instructions and that you are eligible to participate in the study.

blocks.title: Usefulness and Preference Survey
blocks.ask:
Rank how USEFUL you found the four map designs for completing the map tasks on a scale of 1-7.
(1 = Least Useful, 7 = Most Useful)

Rank your personal PREFERENCE of the four map designs regardless of the map tasks on a scale of 1-7.
(1 = Least Preferred, 7 = Most Preferred)
</br>Do you have any additional thoughts, opinions, or concerns about the four map designs?

blocks.title: </br>Usefulness and Preference Survey
blocks.ask:
Rank how USEFUL you found the provided interactive features for completing the map tasks on a scale of 1–7.
(1 = Least Useful, 7 = Most Useful)

Rank your personal PREFERENCE of the provided interactive features regardless of the map tasks on a scale of 1-7.
(1 = Least Preferred, 7 = Most Preferred)
</br>Do you have any additional thoughts, opinions, or concerns about the interactive features?

blocks.title: </br>Background Survey
blocks.ask: </br>How old are you?
</br>What is your gender identity?
</br>Do you have corrected vision?
</br>Do you have color vision impairment (i.e., colorblind)?
</br>Is English your first language?
</br>Are you fluent in English?

blocks.title: </br>Familiarity and Interest Survey
blocks.ask:
Please rate your KNOWLEDGE of the following topics on a scale of 1-7:
(1 = I do not know anything about this topic, 4 = I have an average understanding of this topic, 7 = I know a lot about this topic)

Please rate your INTEREST of the following topics on a scale of 1-7:
(1 = I do not know anything about this topic, 4 = I have an average understanding of this topic, 7 = I know a lot about this topic)
</br>How frequently do you participate in research studies on Mechanical Turk?

blocks.title: Technology Survey
blocks.ask: What kind of COMPUTING DEVICE did you use to view and complete the survey?
What best describes the manner you INTERACTED with the map and submitted your survey responses?

Did you DIVERT your attention (e.g., open another website, check your phone) in any way when completing the survey?
Note: this has no bearing on compensation

blocks.title: PART 1: Practice Map
blocks.ask:
Again, thank you for agreeing to participate in this study!

In Part 1, you will presented with a practice map. In this section, you will learn how to: interact with the map, review legends, complete map tasks, and answer survey questions. Your responses are not timed.

blocks.title: PART 2: Maps
blocks.ask:
Congrats! You have just completed the practice map in Part 1.

In this next section, you will be presented with 16 different maps and answer questions about map patterns as you interact with the maps.

The map tasks are timed, so please do not divert your attention when completing the map tasks.

blocks.title: PART 3: Exit Survey
blocks.ask:
Congrats! You have just completed the mapping tasks in Part 2 of the survey and are almost done with this survey.

Next, you will complete an exit survey about your map preferences as well as surveys about your background, interests, and technology used. You will be compensated after completing an exit survey.
